docs.lead_paragraph: Like other Republicans, Senator John Thune of South Dakota, a member of the party's Senate leadership, says he believes that complaints about the health care overhaul go far beyond policy to the more elemental matter of trust. ''I think there a general distrust of the federal government's capacity to manage something like this,'' Mr. Thune told reporters in a conference call on Tuesday morning.
docs.abstract: Sen John Thune says he believes that complaints about health care overhaul go far beyond policy to more elemental matter of trust; tells reporters there is general distrust of federal government's capacity to manage something of such broad scope; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Enjoy those health care meetings? Now, do-it-yourselfers can try one at home. Or at church. The Family Research Council, a conservative Christian organization, has issued an electronic ''Town Hall Kit'' to help its followers, including pastors, set up their own meetings ''to inform and activate the people in your pews and communities'' against the health care overhaul proposals moving through Congress.
docs.abstract: Family Research Council, conservative Christian organization, has issued electronic Town Hall Kit to help its followers set up their own meetings to make case against health care reform (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic advocates will start fanning out across the country on Wednesday in a final end-of-summer heave to demonstrate their support for a health care overhaul. They hope to provide a bit of counterprogramming to the many skeptical and conservative voices that have slowed President Obama's push to change the health care system. The effort will promote a government-run health insurance plan -- the so-called public option, which appears to be on life-support.
docs.abstract: Advocates operating under aegis of Democratic National Committee will start fanning out across America in final end-of-summer campaign to show their support for health care overhaul; more than 1,800 events are planned; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ron Williams, chief executive of the giant insurer Aetna, has been the most vocal insurance executive in favor of an overhaul of the health care system -- as long as it does not include a government-run health plan. On Wednesday, Mr. Williams plans to make that case on the Tavis Smiley talk show on PBS. In the interview, taped ahead of time, Mr. Williams acknowledged that many people, including President Obama, favor creation of a government plan to compete directly with private insurance companies. But he said that issue was a distraction from the true aim of a health overhaul.
docs.abstract: Aetna Chief executive officer Ron Williams has been insurance industry's most vocal supporter of health care overhaul, but his support is conditional on reform not including government-run health plan; says whole question of public option is distraction from real issue: that every American should be covered; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the heat of midday Cambodia on Dec. 31, 1999, I was standing among the tree-eaten ruins of Ta Prohm, one of the many temples that make up the ancient Khmer city of Angkor. I had come a long way from New York to meet a group of friends and celebrate the millennium at the temples, where 10,000 monks would be chanting that night by candle light. But all of a sudden, I felt woozy and had to sit down. Soon, I knew, I wouldn't be celebrating. I asked a friend to take me back to our hotel room, where I lay under the covers, shivering and sweating for the next 24 hours, missing out on all the fun. I had the flu.

headline.main: Health Advice From the Frugal Traveler's Doctor

docs.abstract: With these travel medicine tips, travelers can indulge in all the joys of low-budget travel from street food to hostels without getting sick or going broke.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my column for Wednesday's paper, I talk about an idea that's missing from the current versions of health reform: allowing people to choose an insurance plan other than the ones offered by their employer.
